meeting_annotations.speaker: A. Ali Yanik, PhD (UC Santa Cruz)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, do you actually leave this sample processing largely to human the labor or is is it done after a certain point by the robotic systems like, you know, which can do thousands tests, uh, you know, if you have few of them a day.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a Google Docs presentation titled "Scalog, MZT Meeting Slides". The presentation contains key points about "Precision Surveillance" including gaps, infrastructure, optimization, community surveillance, ideas, and challenges. The presenter is scrolling through the document.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bethany McGregor-USDA-ARS
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, it depends on the number of samples we've got. Most of what I've done so far has been individual, you know, manpower samples, but we do have some high throughput systems we're standing up right now that are going to improve that quite a bit. You know, I think that kind of to your earlier point, there is an opportunity here, you know, if we're from again, a vector of standpoint, I know that doesn't apply to everybody, but if we're if we're collecting mosquitoes, if we have a trap that also has one of these color changing devices in it, you still have all of those mosquitoes in that trap. They can feed on that card and and indicate whether or not they're depositing viruses, and then you've still got the individuals if you want to take them back, double check, test those mosquitoes and find out, you know, which species were positive, was it a false positive and there are ways to kind of double check those outcomes as well. So I I don't I I know that there are probably things that might cause a false color change or cause false positives, but I think there are ways to to, you know, have a backup system as well.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a Google Docs presentation titled "Scalog, MZT Meeting Slides". The presentation contains key points about "Precision Surveillance" including gaps, infrastructure, optimization, community surveillance, ideas, and challenges. The presenter is highlighting different sections of the document.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Crystal Hepp - Northern Arizona University
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think also you could probably do the species identification at the same time because you know, you've got like your mitochondrial DNA is going to be different between tarsalis and Quinx for example. So that and that's going to be in the saliva. So that might be an additional opportunity.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Crystal Hepp - Northern Arizona University
meeting_annotations.transcript: So if you had um so I'm just trying to think if you had something that would bind like, you know, this this this piece of DNA but not that piece of DNA or give off a color change when this or that was bound, um that might be another opportunity. I mean another thing just this is thinking kind of like really outside of the box that you know, these mosquitoes, they're also um even if they we we found anyways that even if they um are seeking a trap, so seeking carbon dioxide, often times they still have taken a blood meal. So there might be an additional opportunity then to, you know, can you do a deeper oops, sorry. Um a deeper dive to see what what the blood meal was from. Um and I wonder if you could do that with one of these cards as well because then you're identifying potential hosts out in the in the wildlife community.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Dornhout
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I know we have just a few more minutes left.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a Google Docs presentation titled "Scalog, MZT Meeting Slides". The presentation contains key points about "Precision Surveillance" including gaps, infrastructure, optimization, community surveillance, ideas, and challenges. meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Dornhout
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so I'm going to throw out one more question for for folks to consider. We've talked, you know, there there there are production facilities, so um everything from feed lots for cattle to to to hog um uh hog facilities in in hog production, um in in the in the industrialized um food animal space, think there a lot of things in place, not saying it's perfect, but there there are a number of things in in place. Uh, someone mentioned earlier challenges in in the small farms, the family farms where um you kind of get that that primordial soup of of zonatic disease that involves pigs, people and poultry that um can can really represent some some significant challenges both from a um you know, a cultural view on on on those farms to introducing surveillance there. So are there are there particular cultural barriers to success that we should be considering as well.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a Google Docs presentation titled "Scalog, MZT Meeting Slides". The presentation contains key points about "Precision Surveillance" including gaps, infrastructure, optimization, community surveillance, ideas, and challenges. The presenter is adding "Surveillance in family farms that can be sources of disease - cultural barriers? Legal barriers?" to the document.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Paola Boggiatto, ARS-USDA
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, so Maya, I come from a small farm in Montana and I can tell you that if um my and my dad has 150 head of cattle and if there was an abortion and he thought that it might be associated with Brucella, he very well might use some card that would tell him what it was going to be, but I can tell you that that whole place would end up burnt um after the fact because they don't want their whole operation shut down and that's exactly what they're terrified of when we have these big agencies coming in. So that's that's a serious concern I think.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a Google Docs presentation titled "Scalog, MZT Meeting Slides". The presentation contains key points about "Precision Surveillance" including gaps, infrastructure, optimization, community surveillance, ideas, and challenges. The presenter is not making any changes to the document.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Paola Boggiatto, ARS-USDA
meeting_annotations.transcript: On top of that, it takes a month to get any kind of result back when you have the vet send, you know, the the rural vet send to the um testing facility. Um, you know what, I I think one one way you do that is um you know, it's not so much about introducing the the technology to fit our needs, but perhaps understanding what are those cultural barriers and then developing technology that would be amenable to use in those situations because even if you have something that's working, if nobody's willing to implement it and certainly going into these areas, um is that going to really do any good to you? I guess is what I'm trying to say. It is developing a technology that is not going to be deployable, going to be useful in the end, right? So I think that's when you you approach it the opposite way. You approach, you know, what's the problem? What are we trying to to develop and then take into consideration those cultural norms, um, you know, and and and then sort of turn it around, right? So it doesn't become necessarily a scientific problem, right? It becomes a social cultural issue.

meeting_annotations.speaker: A. Ali Yanik, PhD (UC Santa Cruz)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Also if you give them like uh total control over the data, right? Uh, they will be more willing to implement it. Uh, like if let's say.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Dornhout
meeting_annotations.transcript: You know, normally a a particular disease, I don't like to report it. I'm not quite familiar with animal diseases, but you know, it may cause me to shut down the farm. And I can tell which animal has it, right? Let's say I have the technology to tell which animal has it. And then like I'm monitoring this, I'm not reporting anyone, right? And then it starts to become a problem. I have 100 cattle, you know, it was one two, I was like I can manage this, I don't have to report anyone. But then it started to become an uncontrollable level, then you know, I might be willing to share that information. And this is also a training exercise because, you know, it happens a couple of times, uh, I think people will be more willing to, you know, share that information earlier in future.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Crystal Hepp - Northern Arizona University
meeting_annotations.transcript: So maybe having the having it in place where they're okay, so they know that if they use this, this could happen and is there going to be some kind of reimbursement if they do have to, you know, have animals replaced. I think that's like the really important part of it, not just saying, okay, we're going to break you. Um that's I think what folks are really worried about.
